So the background is that we won the Keep, the most beautiful large town in the Keep New Zealand beautiful wards last October.  and it's for the year 2019 and in 2020 there'll be new winners announced so we have it until until October 2019 and we'll be applying again for status so hopefully we get it for another year or two. Been talking to council and roading and comms team about getting some signage up around town to celebrate this and it's just taking a little while to get positions that we can use  And in the interim, I did take photos of a bunch of our Welcome to Cambridge signs to also show you and just draw attention to and start a conversation about those. That's the second part of this presentation. So with the Keep New Zealand Beautiful signs, we've got two locations that we permitted to use. One of them has changed since this slide was sent out. And you would have seen what Julie has sent through. So the picture we're looking at there is coming in from the Avanti Drome End.  And on the right-hand side, you've got a welcome to Cambridge sign tucked into the trees there. Originally, we were allowed to repurpose that sign or put a sign down below, which is the mock-up of the next slide. But thank you. We have now been given permission to use the left-hand side of the road. So if we scoot back one. Sorry, Kieran.  We can now use the left-hand side of the road. And the reason I asked for that is because when you're driving into Cambridge, the right-hand side gets lost. Your eye's not naturally drawn to it. You're driving at 50 k's an hour, and it just doesn't get that well seen. So we have got permission to use the left-hand side. And the sign is 2.4 by 1.2, so it's the same size as what you're seeing there with that Welcome to Cambridge sign. If we go to the next slide,  This is a mock-up of what the sign could look like. So this has been done for free by CAS Designs, and it's in keeping with the Keep New Zealand Beautiful branding guidelines as well. But it's by no means a firm and fast vinyl design, so that's up for feedback as well. What I'm really asking from the community board today is would they support and be okay with these signs going, and any feedback around the design of them? And again, we were allowed to either repurpose the first sign you see there, the blue sign, or put the sign with the red markers. So if we go to the next sign, I think, sorry, PowerPoint, thank you. It's just also pointing out the state of that first sign. That's probably one of our worst around town. Next slide.  So that is just a bit of a mock-up of its positioning. It'll be slightly behind that tree that you can see there, but that's roughly what would be 50 meters down the road from that current sign. Go to the next one. So that's a slightly more close-up.  On this one here, you can see the 2019 and then the word winner. We have to have the year on the sign as part of the requirements. The reason it's sort of positioned a bit like that is that we would hope to win it in 2020 and we just repurpose it and take out the winner and put in 2020 in that space.  Go to the next slide, thank you. So who pays for it? CAS Designs has done the design for free. Wrapped Trade offered pre-COVID, so I need to double check again, to make and sponsor the actual signs, and council have advised that they would install them for free. So there's no cost to the Cambridge Community Board. And what happens if we do not win in 2020? The signs can stay there or they can be removed. Most towns leave them up for a good couple of years, so that can be decided at a later stage.  Next slide. So council have advised that they'd like the community board to approve design and concept. text: Kirsty Clark Thank you for having us here tonight. I've also got with me Justine Kennedy, who is the project manager for this piece of work. So,  I'm just going to provide a brief intro and then hand over to Justine. So, my understanding is that we're here tonight just to provide an overview and to respond to any questions that you may have in determining whether you wish to submit to the C4 structure plan.  and, if so, formulate that submission. So, just to start by outlining that this document is currently out for public feedback. We did kick off this engagement process prior to the Alert Level 3 and 4 lockdown.  the process was due to come to a conclusion and we were approached directly by one party seeking an extension. So, that did occur. And then our elected members of council provided a direction to staff that no community engagement processes would come to an end during the COVID-19 lockdown. So, the direction that we've provided and communicated out to the community is that this community engagement process will remain open  until such time as council offices reopen to the public. So, Justine, if it's OK with you, I'll hand over to you just to provide a brief summary of the status of the document and what it's seeking to achieve. And then either of us can be available to respond to questions. Thank you.
speaker: manager

text: Sounds great. Good evening, everybody. It's nice to see all of you. My husband is very handsome, but he's the only face I've seen for quite a while now. So, C4 structure plan. This is about 66 hectares for residential development going on sort of in the  in Leamington, so just balancing out some of that CBD, making sure that stays in the middle of the town, balancing out all the development we've got going on in the northern areas of Cambridge. So as I said, it's for residential development, so we'll be getting 12 to 15 lots per hectare in there.  So Kirstie sort of talked a little bit to this that it's this is a feedback process this is not a legislative or or this is a or a statutory process so we're not as sort of in a plan change or anything like that we just want to go out and get just some feedback from the community on the draft plan.  So the draft structure plan has actually been produced based on technical reports. So we've had things like geotechnical, three waters, transportation, ecological, archaeological reports produced for the structure plan.  And it is intended to be high level. We just want to sort of show people where we sort of think the roads and houses should go. And it also just shows the intention for connectivity, allowing for walking and cycling, protecting that gully, making sure people can kind of access it. And we can really enhance that feature because it is a really, really cool space and our Parks and Reserves team are very keen to sort of keep it, maintain it and enhance it.  already touched on the fact that the feedback process is open until council is open until the council offices are open. And, yeah, we're expecting sort of five to six hundred houses in there. Greg Morgan Fantastic.

text: Yeah, so what we've shown here is a sort of shared walk and cycle path that would run along the top edge of the gully. Now, the reason for that is because the sides of the gully are actually really quite steep and heavily vegetated. So we actually wanted to retain some of that vegetation, especially at sort of the southeastern end of that gully when we had that ecological  survey done they said look it's actually in pretty good condition at that top end so certainly the ecological advice is really just to sort of leave it alone so that's why we've put that shared walk and cycle path at the top. That also ties in quite nicely with a stormwater solution that's been proposed as part of the three waters technical report that we've received and that talks about sort of a swale system  that would run sort of alongside that as well. It would basically just be like a grassy depth. You wouldn't necessarily have water in there sitting or anything like that. And so that would run along that path as well. And it also means that you have your building and fence setbacks that are required by geotechnical, or sorry, that is in line with geotechnical advice that we've received with regard to the stability of that slope. So it's just trying to tie it all in together and best use that space.

text: Just the two things I brought up to start. Sorry.  The leaves around the streets—I know one old—oh, well, she'd probably kill me if she said old, but she is old in my eyes. It was walking, and the leaves are so badly built up in Thomas Place and Moore Street that she kept walking and didn't realise the kerb was quite where it was, and it had a soft landing because the leaves are so badly built up on the intersection of Moore Street and Thomas Place.  She had a soft landing onto the road, mercifully, because it's just one big—it's just covered. The leaves up the street are just covered, absolutely. And it rained there the other night, and, of course, it was flooding right back to the fences, the drains block. Now, I rung the council twice, and they said, well, you've already rung once. And I said, yeah, I know, but it's over 24 hours ago and nothing's happened.  and I drove there tonight and it still hasn't happened. The streets aren't being swept. Does anyone know when they are going to be swept? I saw the street sweeper today on Alpha Street, but I imagine they've got quite a demand.
speaker: jimgoddin

text: I've seen them in town a couple of times.
speaker: suemilner

text: Yeah, I saw it today.
speaker: suemilner

text: They started at five o'clock this morning.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: We had issues at work and I rang them about work and they  a couple of phone calls and eventually came because I really did my nana when I had to get out there in a suit and take the grate out and empty the drain myself. Looked real good. Town's been done, but it's just the streets and the subdivisions.
speaker: jimgoddin

text: Oh, parts of the town aren't being done. Yeah. I'm not sure how we're going to get around this one at the moment.
speaker: suemilner

text: As I say, they started at five this morning and Jenny and I went walking at quarter to seven and there was seven men up the street with motorised blowers going for it. Okay. And then this afternoon we went riding out towards, up Victoria Road and in through new subdivisions and there was the same guys doing the catch pits.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: Okay, so is it a case of the fact that under  level four they just weren't able to get out and do it they hadn't been here for a month because of the of the lockdown yeah and so maybe we just have to hope that gradually it will yeah yeah i'd like to think so yeah because otherwise there will be enough more yeah yeah but when i saw all the guys blowing today i thought well they're really hooking into it so i was quite pleased with the progress okay okay  We'll just keep a BDI and if we ever feel next week that things have not improved, we maybe have to get back to somebody and say, what are you doing?

text: So we've had an update on today.
speaker: manager

text: That would be great, thank you. Thanks, Joe. OK, Roto. Also, the cemetery staff. Yes.  We had a wee incident today where I put my foot down and just told him that he had to have a bit of compassion. The rules are that we can have 10 people at a cemetery plus staff, plus a minister. Now, there is no limits on how many staff we can have there. We had 10 people, we had a minister, and we had four staff there because we were live streaming it for the other 50 or 60-odd that weren't able to be there.  And the sexton came across and threatened to shut me down. I said, just bring it on. That's not happening. And he said, yeah, it is. Anyway, I told him that if he wished, he could go and ask the deceased sister which nephew or niece he hated the most and get them to leave the cemetery. It's been really tough and quite  hard on families. They made the family feel very unwelcome, which was rather an embarrassment. I happened to be sitting on as a funeral director on the council's NZCCC, and we all agreed that, yes, we are  trying to stick to 10 as much as possible, but you have to show compassion when there's 11 or when there's nine, you know, you've just got to... You can't tell some grandchild that, well, I'm sorry, you're the 11th grandchild, you're the ugly one, you need to stay home. So just bringing it to the attention of everyone, because it's not really appropriate that these guys throw a Hollywood in front of families saying that there's 11 or 12 people here.
speaker: jimgoddin

text: and that we'll be closing this funeral down.
speaker: suemilner

text: So I'm trying to get hold of Sally to speak to her about it.
speaker: jimgoddin

text: Yeah. It's very difficult, isn't it?
speaker: suemilner

text: It is a very difficult time, I realise that, and yeah, not for a minute trying to  the fact that it's very awkward for everybody, but we're trying to conduct funerals for—with 10 people, and you try and get a family to choose the 10 best people of that person, that family.
speaker: jimgoddin

text: Yeah, exactly, Jim. Yeah, yeah.
speaker: suemilner

text: We can certainly provide—get Sally to provide an update on processes to the board, to everyone, if that would be helpful.
speaker: manager

text: I would like—I'd like to talk to Sally because, obviously, I've got a family tomorrow that is 10 people and potentially one grandchild who happens to be here from London. Now, she doesn't—she's stuck in New Zealand. She can't do anything. The parents are coming. As it stands at the moment,  She's going to sit in the car outside the cemetery because she's not allowed in. Now, 11 persons plus—11 persons, 11 people plus a minister, surely we can—you know, we've got to have a little bit of compassion. Everything else is—the funeral director is allowed to sort of—we know the rule. We know we were allowed to go limits. I realise 19's not 10, but surely 11's can be stretched.
speaker: jimgoddin

text: And it's easy enough to maintain the distance. It's not as if we're hugging and shaking hands and kissing and all that sort of thing.
speaker: suemilner

text: We're just saying farewell to someone. Their old man of 90 who's been in the district for 90 years and his granddaughter that's here from London because of COVID who can't get a flight home is not allowed to attend. We've got to stand outside the cemetery because the sextons, I'm just, I don't know  whether she's going to end up coming, but that's potentially what's going to happen. But that was basically what happened today. The family felt very uncomfortable because they wanted to know what was going on and why I got pulled away and what this man in orange was doing.
speaker: jimgoddin

text: Yeah. Well, if you can talk to Sally tomorrow, that might help.
speaker: suemilner

text: Yeah, I hope so.
speaker: jimgoddin

text: Very awkward. Don't envy your job, Jim.

text: No, well, at the moment, the whiskey bottle's getting used a lot, but anyway.

text: Yeah. Okay. Right. Well, I think at this point, we'll meet until close, and thank you all for attending, and I hope it goes better for you tomorrow, Jim.
